name: All or Nothing Thinking
description: Placing people or situations in 'either/or' categories - there is no middle ground.
_If I'm not perfect, I have failed._
_Either I do it right or not at all._

name: Mentally Filtering
description: Only paying attention to certain types of evidence.
Noticing our failures but not seeing our successes.

name: Jumping to Conclusions
description: Mind reading: _Imagining we know what others are thinking._
Fortune telling: _Predicting the future._

name: Emotional Reasoning
description: Assuming that because we feel a certain way what we think must be true.
_I feel embarrassed so I must be an idiot._

name: Labelling
description: Assigning labels to oursleves or other people.
_I'm a loser._
_I'm completely useless._
_They're such an idiot._

name: Overgeneralizing
description: Seeing a pattern based upon a single event, or being overly broad in the conclusions we draw.
_Everything is always rubbish._
_Nothing good ever happens._

name: Disqualifying the Positive
description: Discounting the good the positive things that have happened or that we have done for some reason or another.
_That doesn't count._

name: Magnification and Minimization
description: Blowing things out of proportion (catastrophising), or inappropriately shrinking something to make it seem less important.

name: Shoulds
description: Using critical words like 'should', 'must' or 'ought' can make us feel guilty, or like we have already failed.
If we apply 'shoulds' to other people, the result is often frustration.

name: Personalization
description: Blaming ourselves or taking responsibility for something that wasn't completely our fault. Conversely, blaming other people for something that was our fault.

name: Control Fallacies
description: If we feel externally controlled, we see ourselves as helpless a victim of fate.
However, the fallacy of internal control has us assuming responsibility for the pain and happiness of everyone around us.

name: Fallacy of Fairness
description: Feeling resentful because we think that we know what is fair, even if others disagree.

name: Fallacy of Change
description: Expecting that other people will change to suit us if we just pressure them enough.

name: Always Being Right
description: When a person engages in this distortion, they are continually putting other people on trial to prove that their own opinions and actions are the absolute correct ones.

name: Heaven's Reward Fallacy
description: The false belief that our sacrifice and self-denial will eventually pay off, as if some global force is keeping score.
